Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story:
I stood in the workshop, the scent of sawdust thick in the air, my hands running over the worn handles of my tools. The home loan repayment loomed in my mind, a heavy shadow that pressed on my chest. I needed to take on more jobs, work longer hours, make sure there was enough in the bank for my family. My kids depended on me to keep a roof over their heads, and I couldn’t let them down.

But as a carpenter, I knew the risks of rushing. Every nail, every saw blade, every piece of equipment needed careful inspection before I started the day’s work. Skipping safety checks could mean an accident—an injury that would keep me from earning anything at all. My boss expected me to follow every protocol, and my crew relied on me to set the standard.

I stared at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away. If I took the time to check every tool, I’d lose precious hours—hours I needed to finish the job and get paid. But if I hurried, I risked everything. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands, torn between my family’s needs and the safety of my hands.
